comment.narrative: Since this is a new initiative to build national capacities to meet new requirements and funds have already been mobilized for the Capacity Building Initiative for Transparency (CBIT), established under the Paris Agreement, there have been no other country or regions implemented before. The objective of the project is therefore to establish and manage a CBIT Global Coordination Platform for sharing and obtaining information, disseminate knowledge about the Paris Agreement transparency framework for more efficient donor support, easy and free access to knowledge and ultimately strengthen national transparency systems responding to article 13 of the Paris Agreement. The operationalization of the GCP will be accompanied by regional workshops for knowledge sharing and needs and gaps assessments to inform a more coordinated and efficient capacity building effort.

Component 2: During the reporting period, the project successfully organized the third and final global meeting, held in Rome, Italy, in collaboration and with the technical and financial support of the Ministry of Environment, Land and Sea Protection. The meeting saw the participation of 42 country representatives from 36 Developing Countries and 16 country representatives from 10 developed countries, plus the participation of several other representatives from UN Agencies, Italian environmental agencies, GEF, GEF implementing agencies. The workshop was also preceded by a successful coordination meeting, which saw the participation of 49 experts from a broad range of developed countries and international organizations.The average attendance per event was of 85 representatives out of which slightly more than half women.
Component 3: During the reporting period, generated inputs through vis-à-vis and virtual exchanges were put together to become the backbone of a roadmap for phase 2, which was later elaborated with the objective of providing innovative elements for the development of a phase 2. This work was instrumental to the later submission of new proposal to GEF for a new phase of support under the framework of the CBIT Global coordination Platform.40 countries had completed the self-assessment by 30 June 2019. By the time only two countries had not done the self-assessment. An analysis of each of the national self-assessments was done (40 in total) and made available on the platform through the country pages. Furthermore, a global analysis of the self-assessments was done and presented in the annual meeting in Rome in May 2019. Finally, a research project is applying the data from the national self-assessments to understand the global needs for capacity building compared to the existing support mechanisms

Component 2: The project has successfully held second global workshop in Berlin, Germany in collaboration with GIZ and BMU, fully achieving the objectives established at the project start. Those events, who had a high participation from countries engaged at different levels with CBIT national projects, have been instrumental to make the country participants familiar both with CBIT and the enhanced transparency frameworks established by the Paris Agreement as well as with the coordination platform to be established under outcome1. Further, those meetings not only counted with the participation of more than 50 developing countries but also with several international organizations (among others, GIZ, UNFCCC, WRI, AFD) and donor countries to CBIT (such as inter alia, the Governments of Canada, Germany, Italy, U.K., USA, Japan). Additionally, coordination meetings have also been organized previous to each global workshop, bringing together donors and organizations alike with the achieved purpose of fostering enhanced coordination on the provision of support and on expectations on CBIT.
Component 3: In coordination with the work done under component 1 (self-assessment tool), support was continuously provided, both in person during global workshops as well as through emails and calls, to CBIT focal points registered on the platform to integrate further information on needs and gaps, with the objective of facilitating the identification of priority areas to be dealt with by CBIT national resources. Further, as per output 3.2, a roadmap for a phase 2 was successfully developed thanks to the inputs generated during the project by both UNDP and UNEP DTU. The roadmap has been instrumental to generate innovative approaches for a proposal for phase 2 later submitted and approved by GEF.
